1:
The king's heart is a stream of water in the hand of Yahweh;\q he turns it wherever he pleases.
\q
2:
Every person's way is right in his own eyes,\q but it is Yahweh who weighs the hearts.


\q
3:
To do what is right and just\q is more acceptable to Yahweh than sacrifice.
\q
4:
Haughty eyes and a proud heart—\q the lamp of the wicked—are sin.


\q
5:
The plans of the diligent lead only to prosperity,\q but everyone who acts too quickly comes only to poverty.
\q
6:
Acquiring riches by a lying tongue\q is a fleeting vapor and a snare that kills.


\q
7:
The violence of the wicked will drag them away,\q for they refuse to do what is just.
\q
8:
The way of a guilty person is crooked,\q but the one who is pure does what is right.


\q
9:
It is better to live on a corner of the roof\q than in a house shared with a quarrelsome wife.
\q
10:
The appetite of the wicked craves evil;\q his neighbor finds no favor in his eyes. 


\q
11:
When the mocker is punished, the naive become wise,\q and when the wise person is instructed, he lays hold of knowledge.
\q
12:
The righteous person watches the house of the wicked person;\q he brings wicked people to disaster.


\q
13:
The one who shuts his ears to the cry of the poor,\q he also will cry out, but he will not be answered.
\q
14:
A gift in secret appeases anger\q and a concealed gift appeases strong wrath.


\q
15:
When justice is done, it brings joy to the righteous person,\q but it brings terror to evildoers.
\q
16:
The one who wanders from the way of understanding,\q he will rest in the assembly of the dead.


\q
17:
Whoever loves pleasure will become poor;\q the one who loves wine and oil will not be rich.
\q
18:
A wicked person is ransom for the righteous person,\q and the treacherous person is ransom for upright people.


\q
19:
It is better to live in the desert\q than with a quarreling and angry wife. 
\q
20:
Precious treasure and oil are in the home of the wise,\q but a foolish man wastes them.

\q
21:
The one who does right and is kind—\q this person finds life, righteousness, and honor.
\q
22:
A wise man scales the city of the mighty ones,\q and he brings down the stronghold in which they trusted.


\q
23:
Whoever guards his mouth and tongue\q keeps himself out of trouble.
\q
24:
The proud and haughty person—"Mocker" is his name—\q acts with arrogant pride.


\q
25:
The desire of the lazy kills him,\q for his hands refuse to work.
\q
26:
All day long he craves and craves more,\q but the righteous person gives and does not hold back.


\q
27:
The sacrifice of the wicked is detestable;\q it is even more detestable when he brings it with evil motives.
\q
28:
A false witness will perish,\q but the one who listens will speak for all time.


\q
29:
A wicked man makes his face hard,\q but an upright person is certain about his ways.
\f + \ft Some modern versions have \fqa but an upright person thinks about his way \fqa* . \f*


\q
30:
There is no wisdom, there is no understanding, and there is no advice\q that can stand against Yahweh.
\q
31: The horse is prepared for the day of battle,\q but the victory belongs to Yahweh.
